Michael Jordan – The King of Defense

Michael Jordan is widely regarded as one of the best basketball players of all time. While his scoring ability often steals the spotlight, his defensive prowess should not be overlooked. Jordan was a tenacious defender who earned numerous awards and accolades for his efforts on that end of the court.

Jordan’s defensive abilities were apparent from the start of his career. As a rookie in the 1984-85 season, he averaged 2.4 steals per game and continued to improve as a defender over the next few seasons. In 1988, Jordan won the NBA Defensive Player of the Year award, becoming the only player in league history to win both that award and the MVP award in the same season.

Jordan’s defensive skills were multifaceted. He was an excellent on-ball defender, using his quickness and agility to stay in front of his opponents and disrupt their shots. He was also a great help defender, always aware of where his teammates were on the court and ready to step in and provie support when needed.

In addition to his DPOY award, Jordan was also named to the NBA All-Defensive First Team nine times, tied for the most in league history. He shares that honor with Gary Payton, Kevin Garnett, and Kobe Bryant. Jordan’s defensive prowess was recognized by his peers and coaches alike, as evidenced by his numerous All-Defensive selections.

Jordan’s defensive efforts were not limited to the regular season, either. He was a key part of the Chicago Bulls’ championship teams in the 1990s, and his defense played a crucial role in those victories. In the NBA Finals, Jordan was named the Most Valuable Player six times, and his defensive efforts were a big reason why.

Michael Jordan’s defensive abilities were a major part of his success as a basketball player. His quickness, agility, and awareness on the court made him a formidable opponent for any player he faced. His numerous awards and accolades for his defense speak to his excellence on that end of the court. While he may be remembered more for his scoring, Jordan’s defense was just as important in his career and deserves recognition as well.

How Many Defensive Awards Did Michael Jordan Win?

Michael Jordan won nine All-Defensive First Team honors during his NBA career. This award is given to the best defensive players in the league and is voted on by a panel of sportswriters and broadcasters. Jordan’s nine selections to the All-Defensive First Team tie him for the third-most in NBA history, behind only Kobe Bryant and Kevin Garnett, who each have eleven selections. Jordan’s ability to excel on both offense and defense is a testament to his incredible skill and athleticism as a basketball player.

Was Michael Jordan Good At Defense?

Michael Jordan was considered to be one of the best perimeter defenders in the NBA. He had an impressive average of 2.4 steals per game during his rookie season, whch he continued to build upon in the following years. Throughout his career, Jordan’s defensive skills were highly regarded, and he was known for his ability to anticipate his opponents’ moves, steal the ball, and shut down his opponents’ scoring opportunities. His defensive prowess was showcased in the 1987-88 season, where he averaged 3.2 steals per game and was named the NBA’s Defensive Player of the Year. it can be concluded that Michael Jordan was a highly skilled and effective defender during his career in the NBA.

Did Jordan Ever Win Defensive Player Of The Year?

Michael Jordan won the NBA Defensive Player of the Year award in 1988. This award recognizes the player who has shown exceptional skills in defense during the regular season. Jordan’s win was particularly noteworthy because he also averaged 35 points per game that season, making him the only player in NBA history to win both the DPOY award and average 30 points per game in a single season. It’s worth noting that no other DPOY winner has ever averaged 30 points per game in any season of their career.

How Many Times Was Michael Jordan All Defense?

Michael Jordan was selected to the NBA All-Defensive first team a total of nine times during his career. This achievement puts him in a tie with Gary Payton, Kevin Garnett, and Kobe Bryant for the most All-Defensive first team selections in NBA history. Jordan was widely regarded as one of the best defenders in the league during his playing days, and his nine first team selections are a testament to his defensive prowess.

Conclusion

Michael Jordan’s defensive prowess on the basketball court is just as impressive as his offensive skills. Jordan’s ability to steal the ball and defend the perimeter made him one of the best defenders of all time. He won the Defensive Player of the Year award in 1988, the same year he averaged 35 points per game. This feat has nevr been matched by any other player in NBA history. Jordan was also named to the NBA All-Defensive First Team nine times, tying him with Gary Payton, Kevin Garnett, and Kobe Bryant for the most selections. Jordan’s defensive abilities were a key factor in his success on the court and helped him lead the Chicago Bulls to six NBA championships. His legacy as one of the greatest basketball players of all time is firmly established, and his defensive awards and accomplishments are a testament to his greatness on both ends of the court.

William Armstrong

results.title: How Many Defensive Awards For Michael Jordan - StatMuse
results.content: Michael Jordan played 15 seasons for the Bulls and Wizards. He averaged 30.1 points, 6.2 rebounds, 5.3 assists and 2.3 steals in 1,072 regular-season games. He was selected to play in 14 All-Star games. He won the Rookie of the Year award, 1 Defensive Player of the Year award, 5 MVP awards, 6 Finals MVP awards and 6 NBA championships. He was inducted into the Hall of Fame in 2009.

College statistics[edit]
The three-point line did not exist during Michael Jordan's freshman and junior seasons in North Carolina in the NCAA. During his sophomore season, the three-point line was tested within ACC play. Many other conferences also tested with the line during this season, but again, only within their respective conference competition.

No other player in NBA history has more than 1 40ppg+ average in a playoff series of any length. Jordan did it 5 times.
Elgin Baylor 1962 vs the Celtics (40.6 ppg on 43 FG%), Jerry West 1965 vs the Bullets (46.3 ppg on 45 FG%), Rick Barry 1967 vs the 76ers (40.8 ppg on 40 FG%), Bernard King 1984 vs the Pistons (42.6 ppg on 60 FG%) are the only players ever to accomplish this feat.
Jordan was also the last player in history to do this when he averaged 41.0 ppg in the NBA Finals of 1993 vs the Suns.
Jordan by himself has 5 of the top 7 highest scoring playoff series displays in NBA history.

Only rookie in NBA history to lead his team in four statistics (1984–85)
Jordan led the 1984–85 Chicago Bulls in scoring (28.2 ppg), rebounding (6.5 rpg), assists (5.9 apg) and steals (2.4 spg).
Jordan again led the Bulls in four statistics in 1987–88, this time leading the team in scoring (35.0 ppg), assists (5.9 apg), steals (3.2 spg) and blocked shots (1.6 bpg).
Second rookie in NBA history to average 20+ points, 5+ rebounds, and 5+ assists (1984–85)
Oscar Robertson (1960–61), LeBron James (2003–04) and Tyreke Evans (2009–10) have also achieved this.
Jordan averaged 28.2 points, 6.5 rebounds and 5.9 assists per game. He led all rookies in scoring and steals (2.4 per game).
One of two players in NBA history to score 3,000 points in a season: 3,041 points scored in 82 games played (37.1 ppg) (1986–87)
Wilt Chamberlain is the only other player to achieve this, a feat he accomplished three times.[26]
First player in NBA history to record 200 steals and 100 blocked shots in a season: 236 steals, 125 blocks (1986–87)[42]
Hakeem Olajuwon (1988–89) and Scottie Pippen (1989–90) are the only other players to do so.
Only player in NBA history with more than one season of 200 steals and 100 blocked shots: 259 steals, 131 blocks (1987–88)[42]
Only player in NBA history to lead the league in scoring and win Defensive Player of the Year in the same season (1987–88)[42]
Jordan averaged 35 points per game.
First player in NBA history to win Rookie of the Year, Defensive Player of the Year and Most Valuable Player during his career
David Robinson is the only other player to achieve this.
Hakeem Olajuwon won Defensive Player of the Year and Most Valuable Player during his career, but finished second in Rookie of the Year voting to Jordan in 1984–85.
First player in NBA history to lead the league in scoring and win Defensive Player of the Year during his career
David Robinson is the only other player to achieve this.
Only player in NBA history to lead the league in scoring, win Most Valuable Player, and Defensive Player of the Year in the same season (1987–88)[42]
First player in NBA history to win Most Valuable Player and Defensive Player of the Year in the same season (1987–88)[42]
Hakeem Olajuwon (1993–94) and Giannis Antetokounmpo (2019–20) are the only other players to achieve this.
First player in NBA history to lead the league both in scoring and steals in the same season (1987–88, 1989–90, 1992–93)
Allen Iverson is the only other player to do so, and has performed the feat twice.
Fourth player in NBA history to lead the league in scoring and win the NBA championship in the same season
Jordan is the only player to achieve this more than once; he did this six times (1990–91, 1991–92, 1992–93, 1995–96, 1996–97, 1997–98)
One of three players in history to sweep the Most Valuable Player awards for the regular season, All-Star Game and NBA Finals in the same season (1995–96, 1997–98)
Willis Reed (1969–70) and Shaquille O'Neal (1999–2000) are the only other players to achieve this; Jordan is the only player to perform the feat twice.
One of three players in history to win an Olympic gold medal both as an amateur and professional (1984, 1992)
Patrick Ewing and Chris Mullin have also achieved this, playing on the same teams with Jordan.
Sixth player in history to win an Olympic gold medal, NCAA championship and NBA championship
Clyde Lovellette, Bill Russell, K.C. Jones, Jerry Lucas, Quinn Buckner and Earvin "Magic" Johnson have also achieved this.
Only player in NBA history to win Rookie of the Year (1984–85), Defensive Player of the Year (1987–88), NBA MVP (1987–88, 1990–91, 1991–92, 1995–96, 1997–98), All-Star MVP (1988, 1996, 1998), and Finals MVP (1991, 1992, 1993, 1996, 1997, 1998)
Led the 1995–96 Chicago Bulls to the second-best regular season record in NBA history (72 wins, 10 losses)
Jordan averaged a league-leading 30.4 ppg
The 2015–16 Golden State Warriors, who won 73 regular-season games, are the winningest regular season team in NBA history.
Led the 1995–96 Chicago Bulls to the best combined regular season and postseason record in NBA history (87 wins, 13 losses)

Wins and losses[edit]
During his time in the NBA, the Chicago Bulls teams on which Michael Jordan played set numerous league records for winning, both in the regular season and postseason. However, since wins and losses are a team achievement, only lesser known statistics are listed here.
The longest losing streak of his career was eight games, which occurred during his third stint in the NBA, with the Washington Wizards (November 4 to 22, 2001).
The longest losing streak of his Chicago Bulls career was six games, which occurred twice (March 9 to 17, 1987 and April 6 to 16, 1989). This latter losing streak began with the last game of Jordan's triple-double streak.
The longest losing streak of the Chicago Bulls dynasty era was three games, which occurred at the very beginning of the era (November 2 to 6, 1990).
The longest winning streak of his career was 18 games, which occurred from December 29, 1995, to February 2, 1996. At the time, it was tied for the third longest winning steak in NBA history, and is now tied for the 11th longest winning streak in NBA history. It is the longest winning streak in Chicago Bulls franchise history.
The Chicago Bulls also set the NBA playoff record for consecutive road victories at eight, across the 1991 and 1992 postseasons. It was later broken by the Los Angeles Lakers during a stretch from 2001 to 2002.
